segments.en: “Once upon a time, mendicants, a battle was fought between the gods and the demons.

segments.pli: Tasmiṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, saṅgāme asurā jiniṃsu, devā parājiniṃsu.
segments.en: In that battle the demons won and the gods lost.

segments.pli: Parājitā ca kho, bhikkhave, devā apāyaṃsveva uttarenamukhā, abhiyaṃsveva ne asurā.
segments.en: Defeated, the gods fled north with the demons in pursuit.

segments.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo mātali saṅgāhakaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
segments.en: Then Sakka, lord of gods, addressed his charioteer Mātali in verse:
in the red silk-cotton woods with your chariot pole.
I’d rather give up our lives to the demons
than deprive these birds of their nests.’

segments.pli: ‘Evaṃ, bhaddantavā’ti kho, bhikkhave, mātali saṅgāhako sakkassa devānamindassa paṭissutvā sahassayuttaṃ ājaññarathaṃ paccudāvattesi.
segments.en: ‘Yes, lord,’ replied Mātali. And he turned the chariot back around, with its team of a thousand thoroughbreds.

segments.pli: ‘paccudāvatto kho dāni sakkassa devānamindassa sahassayutto ājaññaratho.
Dutiyampi kho devā asurehi saṅgāmessantī’ti bhītā asurapurameva pāvisiṃsu.
segments.en: The demons will have to fight the gods a second time!’ Terrified, they retreated right away to the castle of the demons.

segments.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, sakkassa devānamindassa dhammena jayo ahosī”ti.
segments.en: And that’s how Sakka came to win victory by principle.”

suttaplex.blurb: Fleeing the demon host, Sakka’s chariot risks endangering the nests of little birds in the forest. Rather than render the birds homeless, Sakka instructs his charioteer to turn back, even at the cost of his life.
